description: The window global object represents a browser tab or iframe and its relationship to the document and other tabs. It's also a generic global object, under which many other APIs are located.
description_html: The window global object represents a browser tab or iframe and its relationship to the document and other tabs. It's also a generic global object, under which many other APIs are located.
name: Window

nodejs.notes: The Window interface is not implemented, but some methods, and properties are available in the global scope.

notes: Apart from firing the event on window as other browsers do, Firefox also fires the event on the document object. See bug 1228802.
Before Firefox 24, the interface for this event is a plain Event, not FocusEvent.
Apart from firing the event on window as other browsers do, Firefox for Android also fires the event on the document object. See bug 1228802.
Before Firefox for Android 24, the interface for this event is a plain Event, not FocusEvent.

edge.notes: Before Edge 79, scripts can close windows that weren't opened by the same script.

firefox.notes: Before Firefox 46, scripts can close windows that weren't opened by the same script.

firefox_android.notes: Before Firefox for Android 46, scripts can close windows that weren't opened by the same script.

chrome.notes: Starting in Chrome 66, opening a popup in fullscreen mode and calling this function will end fullscreen mode.

notes: Apart from firing the event on window as other browsers do, Firefox also fires the event on the document object. See bug 1228802.
Before Firefox 24, the interface for this event is a plain Event, not FocusEvent.
Apart from firing the event on window as other browsers do, Firefox for Android also fires the event on the document object. See bug 1228802.
Before Firefox for Android 24, the interface for this event is a plain Event, not FocusEvent.

firefox.notes: From version 4 to 24, this property could give a wrong value before page load in certain circumstances (see bug 641188).

firefox_android.notes: Before version 24, this property could give a wrong value before page load in certain circumstances (see bug 641188).

safari_ios.notes: This property returns the height of the visual viewport instead of the layout viewport. See bug 174362 for details.

webview_ios.notes: This property returns the height of the visual viewport instead of the layout viewport. See bug 174362 for details.

firefox.notes: From version 4 to 24, this property could give a wrong value before page load in certain circumstances (see bug 641188).

firefox_android.notes: Before version 24, this property could give a wrong value before page load in certain circumstances (see bug 641188).

safari_ios.notes: This property returns the width of the visual viewport instead of the layout viewport. See bug 174362 for details.

webview_ios.notes: This property returns the width of the visual viewport instead of the layout viewport. See bug 174362 for details.

firefox.notes: Before Firefox 86, if a new page from another domain is loaded into a tab, then window.name is not set to an empty string, which can allow some cross-site attacks. See bug 1685089 and bug 444222.

firefox_android.notes: Before Firefox for Android 86, if a new page from another domain is loaded into a tab, then window.name is not set to an empty string, which can allow some cross-site attacks. See bug 1685089 and bug 444222.

safari_ios.notes: This method will not function if the target parameter is unspecified or set to _blank.

webview_ios.notes: This method will not function if the target parameter is unspecified or set to _blank.

firefox.notes: Since Firefox 7, it's no longer possible for a web site to change the default size of a window in a browser if the window wasn't created by window.open or contains more than one tab. See here for more details.

Since Firefox 7, it's no longer possible for a web site to change the default size of a window in a browser if the window wasn't created by window.open or contains more than one tab. See here for more details.

chrome.notes: Chrome does not fire a resize event on page load.

chrome_android.notes: Chrome Android does not fire a resize event on page load.

edge.notes: Before Edge 79, Edge fired a resize event on page load. This is no longer the case.

firefox.notes: Before Firefox 68, Firefox fired a resize event on page load. This is no longer the case.

firefox_android.notes: Before Firefox for Android 68, Firefox for Android fired a resize event on page load. This is no longer the case.

oculus.notes: Quest Browser does not fire a resize event on page load.

opera.notes: Opera does not fire a resize event on page load.

opera_android.notes: Opera does not fire a resize event on page load.

samsunginternet_android.notes: Samsung Internet does not fire a resize event on page load.

webview_android.notes: WebView does not fire a resize event on page load.

firefox.notes: Before Firefox 28, Gecko was using device pixels instead of CSS pixels; in other words, it was assuming a value of screenPixelsPerCSSPixel of 1 for any device.

firefox_android.notes: Before Firefox for Android 28, Gecko was using device pixels instead of CSS pixels; in other words, it was assuming a value of screenPixelsPerCSSPixel of 1 for any device.

firefox.notes: Before Firefox 28, Gecko was using device pixels instead of CSS pixels; in other words, it was assuming a value of screenPixelsPerCSSPixel of 1 for any device.

firefox_android.notes: Before Firefox for Android 28, Gecko was using device pixels instead of CSS pixels; in other words, it was assuming a value of screenPixelsPerCSSPixel of 1 for any device.

firefox.notes: Starting in Firefox 6, this property is read only, as defined by the standard.
